subject: Re: A couple of questions from a newbie
msgSnippet: Scott, I will do that.  Thanks for a very clear explanation.
messageBody:
Scott,

I will do that. Thanks for a very clear explanation.

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "guanolto" <scott@...> wrote:
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "stratocat6969" <john-> Yes, I'm from Ontario, and I can see that I may gravitate to #34 and not worry too much about the subtleties of #32 and #33. There are some minor differences in how I pronounce those, but #34 does the trick in most cases. I am preserving #32+#25 as I find it easier to write, and I just treat it as a single sound.
>
> /Hi John,
>
> Since you're starting out I want to recommend taking a careful look at your usage of #32/33/34: These represent three different sounds in British English which have largely converged in American and Canadian English. If you're from Ontario, then I'm guessing that your pronunciation is extremely similar to mine in California.
>
> The vowel which letter #33 represents is basically the same as for #32, except that with #33 you're also rounding your lips. (Most people don't realize that.) The sound of letter #33 occurs frequently in Britain, as well as New York / New Jersey / New England. In my pronunciation the #33 never occurs at all, as it's totally replaced by #32. In my speaking the sound of #34 is also almost completely replaced by #32; I have the #32 sound only before an "l" or an "r", and in dipthongs (in which case it's not written in QS, of course, since it has specific letters for diphthongs).
>
> Anyway, just want to encourage you to look carefully at those, regardless of what conclusions you reach.
>
> Kind Regards,
>
> Scott
>

Scott,
